GRANT AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Beneficiaries  The  Kingdom  of  Cambodia,  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic 
Republic (Lao PDR), and the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam 
   
Classification  Sector: Health, nutrition, and social protection 
Subsector: Health systems 
Themes: Regional cooperation, Inclusive social development, and 
Gender and development 
Subthemes: Indigenous peoples, and Gender equity in 
opportunities 
Targeting Classification: Targeted intervention 
   
Environment  Environmental Category: C 
Assessment  The  Project  will  not  have  significant  adverse  environmental 
effects. It will finance basic health services, which leave limited 
by-products, and will help safeguard the environment by putting in 
place an early warning and response system, which will reduce 
the environmental costs of disease control, in particular insecticide 
spraying. Medical wastes will be closely monitored.  
   
Project Description  The Governments of Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam (the 
CLV  countries)  propose  a  4-year  regional  project  to  improve 
communicable disease control (CDC) at regional, national, and 
provincial levels in partnership with the Western Pacific Regional 
Office  (WPRO)  of  the  World  Health  Organization  (WHO).  The 
Design and Monitoring Framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
The Project will strengthen the regional capacity to contain the 
spread of emerging diseases and reduce the burden of common 
endemic  communicable  diseases  within  the  framework  for 
regional collaboration of the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS). It 
will (i) strengthen national surveillance and response systems, (ii) 
improve CDC for vulnerable groups, and (iii) strengthen regional 
collaboration in CDC. The targeted provinces are important for 
CDC  because  of  regional  connectivity,  their  high  burden  of 
infectious diseases, and the high degree of vulnerability of their 
populations.   
 
The  first  component  of  the  Project  will  help  develop 
comprehensive national surveillance and response systems in the 
three  countries  and  develop  community-based  models  for 
controlling outbreaks of diseases, including avian influenza, in 26 
provinces (5 in Cambodia, 6 in Lao PDR, and 15 in Viet Nam). 
Institutional  structures  based  on  the  new  international  health 
regulations (IHR) will be developed; preparedness, surveillance, 
and response will be improved; district laboratory services will be 
improved; and human resources will be developed.

iii
  The  second  component  will  expand  and  integrate  CDC  for 
vulnerable  groups  in  26  priority  provinces  by  (i)  strengthening 
provincial capacity for CDC; (ii) supporting comprehensive CDC 
for  vulnerable  groups,  including  control  of  neglected 
communicable diseases like dengue and parasitic infections; and 
(iii) improving the continuum of care for the control of human 
immunodeficiency  virus/acquired  immunodeficiency  syndrome 
(HIV/AIDS) in high-risk populations. 
  
The third component will develop productive regional coordination 
for CDC through regional policy dialogue, operations research for 
HIV/AIDS  control  and  other  fields  through  regional  institutions, 
and project management. The People’s Republic of China (PRC), 
Myanmar, and Thailand will be invited to participate in regional 
workshops. 
 
Rationale  The CLV countries have made remarkable progress in improving 
the health of their populations over the past decades, and are 
making major efforts to putting in place strong policy frameworks 
and primary health care (PHC) systems. However, as discussed 
at  the  Fifth  Meeting  of  the  GMS  Working  Group  on  Human 
Resource  Development  in  Yangon  in  June  2004,  the  CLV 
countries may not achieve their health-related MDGs based on 
current challenges and efforts.   
 
To  achieve  health-related  MDGs  requires  providing  PHC  to 
remote populations suffering from a high burden of infectious and 
reproductive diseases, and improving the affordability and quality 
of  health  care.  This  is  further  complicated  by  the  need  for 
community  action  to  contain  emerging  diseases  like  avian 
influenza  and  severe  acute  respiratory  syndrome  (SARS), 
dengue, and HIV/AIDS, which are facilitated by increased market 
integration, connectivity, and movements of people and goods.  
 
At the GMS summit meeting in 2005, the six heads of government 
reaffirmed their vision of a subregion free from poverty and able to 
provide  sustainable  development  opportunities  for  their 
populations.  Besides  economic  cooperation  and  integration, 
human  development  was  appreciated  as  the  crux  of  the 
Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) for reducing poverty. The 
leaders proposed stronger regional collaboration in CDC in view 
of  HIV/AIDS  and  emerging  infectious  diseases  like  avian 
influenza, as part of national health systems development.  
 
.

iv 
 
  Regional cooperation in CDC is justified if benefits exceed what 
countries acting on their own can achieve. In CDC, the rationale 
for  regional  cooperation  can  be  broken  down  into  four  broad 
categories, namely: (i) transmission of communicable diseases, 
(ii)  technology  transfers,  (iii)  economies  of  scale  and  greater 
leverage, and (iv) regional public goods for health. 
 
CDC and health systems in general have developed in relative 
isolation. International boundaries reinforced national approaches 
to health systems and disease control in the “pre-globalization” 
era, when borders barred the movement of people and goods. 
However, in recent years, globalization has transformed borders 
from  barriers  to  bridges,  and  this  transformation  has  shifted 
attention to cross-border matters that localities have in common.  
 
The emergence in the GMS of SARS and avian influenza have 
demonstrated  that  the  economic  impact  from  these  diseases 
amounts to billions of dollars through declining tourism, reduced 
flows of foreign investment, and export restrictions on livestock 
and animal products. A human avian influenza pandemic may 
cause millions of deaths and an economic meltdown. To enhance 
national  economic  and  health  security,  epidemics  must  be 
contained at their source and their potential spread in the region 
minimized. This will require strong regional efforts for CDC. 
 
The revised IHR of WHO, approved in May 2005, will serve as the 
new legal framework for actions to prevent the spread of disease 
internationally. Under the new IHR, countries will be expected to 
report any public health threat. They will establish and maintain 
minimum  core  surveillance  and  response  capacities  to 
successfully implement the global health security, epidemic alert, 
and response strategy. 
 
Regional economic developments, emerging diseases and their 
economic impact, and high-level political commitment to attaining 
MDGs have generated strong support for regional cooperation 
across health sectors. The current GMS setting favors a regional 
approach to CDC that can significantly improve the health of the 
poor in the CLV countries.  
 
   
Impact and Outcome  The overall anticipated impact of the GMS Regional CDC Project 
is to contain the spread of epidemic diseases at local level and 
reduce  the  burden  of  common  endemic  diseases  in  the  CLV 
countries by about 15% in the targeted provinces, and more for 
certain specific infections. This will help these countries progress 
toward their health-related MDGs for 2015 of reducing the child 
mortality rate and containing the spread of HIV/AIDS and other 
infections.

v
  The  expected  project  outcomes  are  (i)  timely  and  adequate 
control of epidemics that are likely to have a major impact on 
public  health  and  the  economy  in  the  region;  (ii)  improved 
coverage of prevention and care of communicable diseases in 
vulnerable  populations;  and  (iii)  improved  know-how,  policies, 
standards,  and  coordination  among  countries  to  improve  CDC 
including for HIV/AIDS through intergovernmental cooperation.  
 
Activities under the Project are pro-poor, focusing on PHC and 
community-based  activities  in  priority  provinces.  Women  and 
children will be the major beneficiaries of community interventions. 
Priority will be given to CDC in remote areas including border 
provinces where many ethnic groups and the poorest reside. 
   
Cost Estimates  The  Project  is  estimated  to  cost  approximately  $38.75  million, 
including duties and taxes. Of the total, $19.73 million or 51% is 
the foreign exchange cost and $19.02 million equivalent or 49% 
represents the local currency costs. 
   
Financing Plan  The Governments have requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to provide a grant of $30.0 million from its Special Funds 
resources  (Asian  Development  Fund  IX  Grants  Program), 
representing 77.4% of the total project cost. WHO will contribute 
$0.9 million for technical experts. The Governments will provide 
counterpart  funds  totaling  $7.85  million  equivalent,  including 
Cambodia $1.98 million, Lao PDR $1.32 million, and Viet Nam 
$4.55 million.

Executing Agencies  The Ministries of Health of Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet Nam will 
be the Executing Agencies. 
   
Implementation  In Cambodia, project implementation will be guided by the health 
Arrangements  sector steering committee (SC) of the Ministry of Health (MOH), 
which is chaired by the Minister of Health. The Communicable 
Diseases  Control  Department  will  be  the  coordinating 
Implementing Agency (IA). The health sector support program will 
provide administrative support. Three national institutions and five 
provinces will also serve as IAs.  
 
In the Lao PDR, project implementation will be guided by the 
MOH SC, chaired by the Minister of Health. The Department of 
Hygiene and Prevention will be the coordinating IA, and will be 
supported  by  the  Department  of  Planning  and  Budgeting  in 
planning,  procurement,  financial  management,  and  reporting. 
Three national institutions and six provinces will also serve as IAs.  
 
In Viet Nam, project implementation will be guided by the MOH 
SC  for  ADB-funded  projects,  chaired  by  the  Vice-Minister  of 
Health for Preventive Services. The Viet Nam Administration of 
Preventive  Medicine  will  be  the  EA  and  coordinating  IA.  Four 
national institutions and 15 provinces will also serve as IAs.

vii
  For the region, the regional CDC SC formed under the project 
preparatory technical assistance will continue to meet every  6 
months, with the hosting rotated among the countries. Its function 
is advisory. It will give guidance in project implementation, policy 
dialogue, and the building of regional capacity and cooperation for 
CDC, and will facilitate country decisions on the use of pooled 
funds for regional activities. It will be chaired by the minister or 
vice-minister  of  the  host  country  and  will  consist  of  leading 
representatives from the national SCs, project directors, and ADB 
and WHO representatives. A regional coordination unit (RCU) to 
be  set  up  in  Hanoi  will  act  as  the  secretariat  for  regional 
coordination activities and the management of regional funds.  
 
To facilitate the flow of funds for regional activities, $4.3 million, or 
11%  of  the  project  funds,  will  be  administered  by  ADB  as  a 
regional  CDC  fund  for  regional  collaboration, managed  by  the 
RCU. This fund will cover expenditures for the Project’s regional 
SC, technical forums, international consulting services, regional 
studies,  cross-border  activities,  and  the  RCU  itself.  ADB’s 
administration  of  the  pooled  regional  funds  is  considered 
necessary to ensure the efficient release of funds. The regional 
CDC fund will be financed from ADB’s share of the grant on the 
basis of a ratio of 30:20:50 for Cambodia, Lao PDR, and Viet 
Nam,  respectively.  The  contribution  to  the  RCU  and  regional 
activities will follow this ratio, subject to country approval, except 
for the financing of studies, for which the country contributions will 
be determined on a case-by-case basis by the regional SC.  
 
WHO has been requested to engage and manage nine types of 
international  consulting  services,  including  for  surveillance  and 
response,  dengue,  and  endemic  diseases,  as  it  has  special 
expertise  in  this  area.  ADB  will  provide  $1.6  million  from  the 
regional  CDC  fund—representing  $0.48  million  of  its  grant 
allocation  for  Cambodia,  $0.32  million  for  Lao  PDR,  and  0.80 
million for Viet Nam—and WHO will provide $0.9 million, for a total 
of  $2.5  million.  This  arrangement  has  been  agreed  to  by  the 
recipients of the grant and is reflected in the grant agreements. 
WHO and  ADB have  agreed to sign a project implementation 
agreement authorizing WHO to recruit and manage international 
experts according to procedures acceptable to ADB and subject to 
the approval of candidates by ADB (see para. 93). The project 
implementation agreement specifies, among others, (i) the type of 
experts to be provided by WHO, (ii) the manner in which these 
experts  will  operate  in  close  coordination  with  MOH,  and 
(iii) implementation  arrangements  for  the  selection  of  experts, 
reporting, disbursement, and performance review.

viii 
 
Procurement  ADB-financed goods and services will be procured according to 
ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement and the relevant laws in each 
country. However, if there is any inconsistency between ADB’s 
requirements  and  the  national  laws,  ADB’s  requirements  will 
prevail.  Equipment  will  be  procured  through  (i)  international 
competitive  bidding  for  contracts  worth  at  least  $1  million; 
(ii) international shopping for contracts worth at least $100,000 but 
less than $1 million for the Governments of Cambodia and Lao 
PDR,  and  at  least  $350,000  but  less  than  $1  million  for  the 
Government  of  Viet  Nam;  and  (iii) local  competitive  bidding  or 
direct purchase for items valued at less than $100,000 for the 
Governments of Cambodia and Lao PDR, and less than $350,000 
for the Government of Viet Nam. The procurement of equipment 
and supplies will be managed by each EA, which may delegate 
this task to IAs for items valued at less than $20,000 in Lao PDR 
and Cambodia, and $50,000 in Viet Nam. 
   
Consulting Services  The Project will provide for 238 person-months of international 
and 1,176 person-months of national consulting services. Of the 
international  consultants,  the  regional  project  coordinator,  the 
health  system  development  expert,  and  the  HIV/AIDS  chief 
technical  adviser  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  as  individual 
consultants for a total of 68 person-months according to ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. International experts for 
surveillance  and  response,  outbreak  preparedness,  virology, 
dengue  control,  control  of  endemic  diseases,  legislation,  and 
health information system will be contracted for a total of 170 
person-months by WHO as implementing agency according to its 
rules and regulations for administrative procedures and practices. 
ADB-funded experts engaged by WHO must first be approved by 
ADB  and  MOH.  Domestic  consultants  will  be  engaged  as 
individual  consultants  by  each  MOH  according  to  procedures 
acceptable to ADB. 
     
Project  Benefits and  The Project will help improve the health of targeted populations 
Beneficiaries  and thereby increase their productivity, and help progress toward 
the health-related MDGs. The Project will improve prevention and 
control of communicable diseases, intergovernmental cooperation 
in  containing  and  eliminating  diseases,  and  also  contribute  to 
strengthening national health systems.  
 
Activities  under  the  Project  are  targeted  toward  the  poor  in 
general  and  those  living  in  remote  locations  including  border 
areas,  where  many  ethnic  groups  and  the  most  poor  reside. 
Women  and  children  will  be  the  major  beneficiaries  of  these 
community-level interventions.

ix
  The economic benefits of the Project will come from (i) helping 
prevent major epidemics; (ii) productivity gains from an increased 
lifespan  and  reduced  mortality;  (iii) productivity  gains  from 
improved  achievements  in  education,  especially  through  less 
absenteeism  and  reduced  dropout  rates;  and  (iv)  public  and 
private savings in health expenditures, including indirect costs.  
 
Risks and Assumptions  The  Project  has  some  technical  risks  in  the  effectiveness  of 
control measures, in particular for dengue and community-based 
surveillance in general. These technical risks will be mitigated by 
partnering  with  WHO,  hiring  more  national  staff  to  build  local 
capacity,  and  strengthening  provincial  and  community 
involvement.  Institutional  networking  and  regional  collaboration 
will also help strengthen the implementation capacity of provinces. 
 
Previous ADB projects showed project management to be critical 
to  achieving  results.  Each  coordinating  IA  will  have  a  project 
management  unit,  which  will  be  supported  by  existing  project 
administrative  capacity  in  each  MOH  in  areas  like  planning, 
procurement, financial management, monitoring, and reporting.    
 
Regional cooperation is known to require considerable front-end 
costs  with  low  immediate  returns  because  of  an  “incubation 
period.”  However,  these  costs  should  be  offset  by  substantial 
benefits from regional disease control, technology transfer, and 
strengthened national commitment for health sector development, 
all of which will have long-term value across the region. ADB will 
need to provide substantial support for regional cooperation and 
ensure that this becomes fully institutionalized in terms of budget, 
staff, responsibility, and authority in the ministries. 
 
The  Project’s  recurrent  costs  amount  to  about  $1.7  million  in 
2009, the final year of implementation, and $1.1 million by 2012. 
The three governments confirmed that the increased recurrent 
cost resulting from the Project can be covered by their respective 
health budgets.

II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Rationale for a Regional Approach  
 
2.  The  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS)  Regional  Communicable  Diseases  Control 
(CDC)  Project  is  a  project  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  in  partnership  with  the 
Western Pacific Regional Office (WPRO) of the World Health Organization (WHO).1 The Project 
will cover three GMS countries that are in great need of assistance in controlling communicable 
diseases—Cambodia,  Lao  PDR,  and  Viet  Nam  (the  CLV  countries)—and  offer  regional 
arrangements for cooperation with People’s Republic of China (PRC), Myanmar, and Thailand.2 
 
3.  Since  1992,  ADB  has  been  supporting  the  GMS  Program  to  increase  economic 
cooperation and integration among Cambodia, the PRC (in particular with Yunnan Province), 
Lao PDR, Myanmar, Thailand, and Viet Nam. At the GMS summit meetings in 2002 and 2005, 
the six heads of government declared their vision of a subregion free from poverty and able to 
provide sustainable development opportunities for their populations. The Regional Cooperation 
Strategy and Program 2004–2008 revolves around four main elements: connectivity and cross-
border facilitation; integration of national markets for economic efficiency and private sector 
development; environmental and natural resource management; and human development.  
 
4.  Regional cooperation is justified if benefits exceed what countries acting on their own 
can achieve. Specifically for CDC, the rationale for regional cooperation can be broken down 
into four broad categories: 
 
(i)  Nature of communicable disease transmission: Communicable diseases are 
transmitted  by  people,  vectors,  food,  and  elements  throughout  a  particular 
geographic region irrespective of national borders.  
 
(ii)  Technology transfer: Regional cooperation enables participating countries to 
share experiences and knowledge about health policies, system design, and 
disease control, and apply lessons learned. These technology transfers also 
facilitate greater consistency, clarity, and transparency among countries in CDC 
and other health matters. 
 
(iii)  Economies  of  scale  and  greater  leverage:  Regional  cooperation  helps  to 
achieve economies of scale for more efficient resource allocation, e.g., sharing 
design work, testing, expertise, and procurement. Also, participating countries 
can acquire greater leverage in attracting donor funding by aggregating particular 
underfunded endemic diseases.

(iv)  Regional public goods for health: Programs to prevent HIV/AIDS and other

prevention programs and the raising of standards across countries will provide

5.  CDC and health systems in general have developed in relative isolation. International 
boundaries reinforced national approaches to health systems and disease control in the “pre-
globalization” era, when borders barred the movement of people and goods. However, in recent 
years, globalization has transformed borders from barriers to bridges, and this transformation 
has shifted attention to cross-border matters that localities have in common. Regional economic 
developments, catalytic events and their economic impact, and high-level political commitment 
to attaining Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) have generated strong support for regional 
cooperation across health sectors. The current GMS setting favors a regional approach to CDC 
that can significantly improve the health of the poor in the CLV countries. 
 
6.  Despite the strong rationale for regional cooperation in CDC and broader health systems 
development, regional initiatives in the GMS health sector have been limited. New approaches 
to CDC are manifested in the Mekong Basin Disease Surveillance Program (MBDSP), financed 
by the Rockefeller Foundation, and the ongoing revision of the international health regulations 
(IHR) by WHO. With the support of MBDSP, a major landmark was achieved in 2001 when the 
six GMS ministers of health signed an agreement to share disease information and cooperate to 
control diseases across borders.  
 
7.  The revised IHR of WHO, approved in May 2005, will serve as the new legal framework 
for actions to prevent the spread of disease internationally. Under the new IHR, countries will be 
expected to report any (potential) epidemic or other public health threat. They will establish and 
maintain minimum core surveillance and response capacities to successfully implement the 
global health security, epidemic alert, and response strategy.3 
 
B.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
8.  As reflected in the United Nations Millennium Statement, “We the Peoples,” human 
development is the crux of poverty reduction and economic growth. Four out of eight MDGs 
relate directly to health and nutrition—reducing child and maternal mortality and malnutrition, 
and  containing  and  beginning  to  reverse  the  trend  of  HIV/AIDS4  and  other  communicable 
diseases. In the GMS and elsewhere, human development plays a major role in economic 
growth and poverty reduction.  
 
9.  The CLV countries have made remarkable progress in improving the health of their 
populations over the past decades, and are making major efforts to putting in place strong policy 
frameworks and expanding primary health care (PHC). However, as discussed at the Fifth 
Meeting of the GMS Working Group on Human Resource Development (HRD) in Yangon in 
June 2004, the CLV countries may not achieve the health-related MDGs of reduction of under-5

10.  Achieving MDGs will require targeting poor and remote populations, women and infants, 
ethnic minorities, and people living in border areas. These populations are suffering from a high 
burden of reproductive illnesses and common infections such as malaria, diarrhea, typhoid 
fever,  acute  respiratory  infections,  measles,  tuberculosis,  and  parasitic  infections.  Without 
appropriate care these diseases result in high mortality, disability, and malnutrition. The impact 
of infectious diseases on learning and productivity is profound.  
 
11.  In the past decade, the region has experienced major increases in HIV/AIDS, hepatitis C 
and dengue, which can spread easier through increased market integration, connectivity, and 
movements of people and goods. Cambodia has a generalized HIV/AIDS epidemic, the Lao 
PDR is surrounded by countries with generalized or concentrated HIV/AIDS epidemics, and Viet 
Nam has a concentrated epidemic in high-risk groups. Social changes and increasing inequity 
are also likely to accelerate the spread of HIV/AIDS.  
 
12.  More recently, the region has been the center of outbreaks of severe acute respiratory 
syndrome (SARS) and avian influenza (AI). Already at this level of relatively minor human 
impact, the economic impact of AI has been substantial, amounting to billions of dollars in 
losses through declining tourism, reduced flows of foreign investment, and export restrictions on 
livestock and animal products. A human AI pandemic may cause millions of deaths and an 
economic meltdown. To enhance national economic and health security, epidemics must be 
contained at their source and their potential spread in the region minimized, requiring regional 
support for CDC. This will require reaching all communities with basic prevention and control 
systems, including those not reached so far.   
 
13.  Since the CLV countries emerged from war, their respective Governments have been 
fully committed to building up a network of PHC facilities and improving human resources. At 
the same time, the private sector has been expanding, with private practitioners, drug shops, 
and  paramedics  becoming  major  providers  of  basic  curative  care.  The  impact  of  these 
developments can be seen in service coverage indicators in Cambodia and the Lao PDR. 
Access to essential drugs now stands at about 50% in Cambodia, 80% in Lao PDR, and 85% in 
Viet Nam. The Lao PDR has achieved this coverage in part through community-based care, in 
contrast to the more institution-based services in the other countries. However, immunization 
rates are lower in the Lao PDR, at about 36–65% compared with 43–76% in Cambodia and 78–
99%  in  Viet  Nam.  Modern  contraceptive  medicine  coverage  among  couples  is  19%  in 
Cambodia, 29% in the Lao PDR, and 56% in Viet Nam, another area of concern.  
 
14.  The market-oriented reforms introduced in the CLV countries in the late 1980s and 
1990s opened up opportunities for private providers. Urban people now have more options in 
selecting their health-care providers. The growth of privately owned pharmacies has made 
drugs and supplies more widely available. However, few private doctors set up clinics in rural 
areas, where the purchasing power is very low. The private sector is largely unregulated and 
often wasteful and of substandard quality. Affordability of health services has been declining as 
the gap between the rich and the poor increases.

15.  In particular, CLV Governments will need to improve access to PHC for vulnerable 
populations, and improve the affordability and quality of health care. Access to health services is 
a  particular  problem  for  ethnic  minorities,  many  of  them  living  in  hilly  areas.  Language

pay for when they require the care. For various reasons, there is a serious lack of qualified staff 
in rural areas. Even more fundamental are problems besetting the health systems themselves 
including low staff salaries, supervision and supply constraints, inadequate integration of vertical 
programs and PHC, limited provincial planning and budgeting capacity, and fiscal constraints. 
An analysis of the challenges in the health sector is in Appendix 3. 
 
16.  Public expenditures on health do not reflect the recent economic gains. Public health 
spending in the CLV countries is still only about 1.6–1.7% of gross domestic product (GDP), 
causing major financial constraints in public health services. But the countries differ widely in 
total health spending, at 11.8% of GDP in Cambodia, 3.1% in the Lao PDR, and 5.1% in Viet 
Nam. Per capita spending per year is $30 in Cambodia, $10 in Lao PDR, and $21 in Viet Nam, 
compared with $49 in PRC, $69 in Thailand, and the international minimum standard of $34. 
About 13% of health spending in Viet Nam is donor-financed, versus about 30% in Cambodia 
and the Lao PDR. Public sector spending in the Lao PDR is about 50% of total health spending, 
compared with 13% in Cambodia and 28% in Viet Nam.  
 
17.  Following the influx of donors after the war, the Government of Cambodia has taken bold 
steps  to  bring  donors  together  under  one  program,  and  contract  out  health  services  to 
nongovernment agencies. The Health Sector Support Plan 2003–07 is the basis for sector-wide 
management by Cambodia’s Ministry of Health (MOH) and serves as an umbrella framework for 
health activities under the National Poverty Reduction Scheme. The plan specifies six key areas 
of  work:  (i)  health  service  delivery,  (ii) behavioral  change  and  communication,  (iii)  quality 
improvement, (iv) HRD, (v) health financing, and (vi) institutional development.6 MOH follows a 
strong  system  approach,  promoting  village  health  support  groups  and  health  center 
management  committees,  integrated  management  of  childhood  illnesses  (IMCI),  consumer 
confidence in health services, and ethical conduct. CDC is to be fully integrated with PHC at 
provincial level and below.   
 
18.  The Government of the Lao PDR has consistently tried to build up the national health 
system, starting from a very limited capacity. It has succeeded in improving access to services, 
but must now operate an expanded health system with scant resources for a largely poor 
population. The country’s MOH has developed a poverty-focused health development plan for 
2005–2010  within  the  general  framework  of  the  National  Growth  and  Poverty  Eradication 
Strategy, the Health Sector Strategy 2020, and the Health Sector Master Plan. The Government 
wants to give every citizen access to essential health care. MOH is undertaking a strategic 
planning exercise, including the preparation of provincial strategic plans and 5-year plans. It is 
also forming task forces to review key subsectors and draw up development plans for them. The 
Government gives high priority to CDC, and has been increasing funding for CDC programs, in 
particular for malaria, tuberculosis, and HIV/AIDS control supported by the Global Fund. While a 
strong PHC network is in place, integration of CDC and PHC needs more work.

C.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
1.  Communicable Disease Priorities 
20.  Emerging Diseases. Outbreaks of newly emerging diseases such as SARS in 2003 and 
AI in 2004 and 2005 have so far had little impact on health in the region, but could have vastly 
more devastating effects. The case fatality rate for SARS is around 10% and for human AI 
about 50%. As of the end of May 2005, 50 people in Viet Nam had died from AI, or 80% of all 
deaths in the region. Cambodia has had four deaths in Kampot province. However, scientists 
indicate that the AI virus may mutate or reassort into another virus that spreads in humans like 
an ordinary flu virus. This could cause a global pandemic with millions of deaths in the region. 
   
21.  These  emerging  diseases,  even  with  limited  health  impact,  have  major  economic 
consequences. SARS slowed economic growth by reducing tourism and communication. GDP 
in the region could have declined by 0.2–1.8 percentage points if SARS had persisted for one 
economic quarter, and, GDP in the individual countries could have fallen by 0.5–4.0 percentage 
points if it had gone on for two quarters.7  While the CLV countries do not have a major poultry 
export industry like Thailand, AI has probably reduced GDP by about 0.5% in Viet Nam.8 More 
importantly, it has had a major impact at the local level on poor backyard farmers and wet 
markets. Viet Nam has culled almost a quarter of its national poultry stock. A human pandemic 
may cause an economic meltdown.   
 
22.  The fast spread of these diseases and their potential consequences highlight the need 
for regional collaboration in CDC. Such a strategy must entail the strengthening of surveillance 
and response systems from community-level workers detecting outbreaks to laboratory facilities 
and provincial and national response centers. Cooperation across the health and agriculture 
sectors is important for AI. AI requires better poultry biosecurity and vaccination, improved 
preparedness and response of public and private services including quarantine arrangements 
and medicines, and risk profiling and monitoring the spread and genotype of the virus in hosts. 
The ministries of agriculture in the region are performing animal surveillance with assistance 
from the Food and Agriculture Organization. Laboratory conditions for the cultivation of the AI 
virus in the national animal health laboratories are substandard and pose a biohazard.

23.  Early and accurate detection is also a vital element in preventing the spread of other 
infectious diseases like measles, dengue, typhoid, and cholera. Beyond the rise of emerging 
diseases, the capacities of the CLV countries’ health systems will be further challenged by 
WHO’s introduction of new IHR mandating that governments report any outbreak of infectious 
diseases (and possibly chemical and radiological threat) starting in June 2006, as discussed 
below. The health surveillance and monitoring systems in the CLV countries already required 
long-term assistance to strengthen the capacity to generate reliable, timely, routine data before 
SARS  and  AI,  and  thus  the  emergence  of  new,  complicated  communicable  diseases  is 
compounding the pressures placed on the surveillance systems. While most diseases require 
basic laboratory procedures, some of them, such as AI, require more complicated laboratory 
procedures for confirmation done in bio-safety level-3 laboratories. 
  
24.  The CLV countries cannot cope with a major outbreak of emerging disease. At present 
there are no human vaccines available for the types of newly emerging diseases that are 
threatening the region. Experience with AI cases in Viet Nam suggests that currently available 
treatment is of limited benefit. Only few hospitals can manage a limited number of AI cases and 
are not prepared for any major epidemic. Even if vaccines and drugs were available, production 
capacity  would  not  be  able  to  cope  with  demand.  While  national  preparedness  plans  are 
available, this has mostly not translated in concrete action plans in the various sectors.  
    
25.  HIV/AIDS. The Lao PDR and Viet Nam now have low prevalence of HIV/AIDS, but both 
countries have neighbors with high prevalence rates, namely, Cambodia and Thailand. Viet 
Nam has a growing HIV/AIDS problem in the form of a concentrated epidemic among high-risk 
groups, including injecting drug users and sex workers. As of 31 May 2005, Viet Nam reported a 
cumulative total of 93,402 cases of HIV cases. The HIV prevalence is about 57% in injecting 
drug users and 3% in sex workers. The infections are concentrated in cities and along the roads 
and borders in hot spots, in particular the borders with Cambodia and the PRC. Cambodia has a 
maturing HIV/AIDS epidemic, with around 1.9% of the population aged 15–49 infected with 
HIV—down from 2.2% in 2001, but an increasing prevalence among rural women. As a result of 
past high infection rates, Cambodia is estimated to have more than 120,000 people now living 
with HIV/AIDS, composing 1.9% of the population aged 15–49. The impact on GDP and the 
cost of health services is substantial. In the Lao PDR, 1,636 HIV positive cases were detected 
between 1990 and 2005. While this figure is low by regional standards, particular “hot spots” in 
the country have emerged, where service women have high HIV prevalence rates; Bokeo, for 
instance, has 4% HIV prevalence among service women, and Savannakhet 3.2%. The Joint 
United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS) expects HIV prevalence in the Lao PDR to 
double every 1–2 years over the next few years. 
 
26.  HIV/AIDS funding for Viet Nam is substantial but further support is particularly needed 
for harm reduction, continuum of care, prevention among youth, and regional collaboration and 
research. Cambodia is currently only able to provide antiretroviral treatment to half of the AIDS 
patients and needs support for continuum of care. While the Lao PDR has low HIV/AIDS 
prevalence, it must expand prevention and care to contain the epidemic as much as possible.   
 
27.  Most activities for HIV/AIDS prevention and control can be handled through national and 
provincial  programs,  but  particular  cross-border  HIV/AIDS  issues  and  challenges  are 
demonstrating the need for selected regional initiatives as well. A major concern is that the inter-
country  mobility  of  people,  facilitated  in  great  part  by  the  provision  of  roads  and  other 
infrastructure with the support of international and regional development institutions, will make 
HIV/AIDS  much  more  difficult  to  prevent  and  control.  Sex  workers,  trafficked  women, 
construction workers, truck drivers, and other mobile groups moving across different parts of the

7
GMS contribute greatly to the spread of the disease and are often beyond the reach of health 
service providers for detection and treatment. Regional cooperation is necessary to address 
these potential sources of transmission. 
 
28.  Neglected Endemic Diseases. Intensive efforts are under way to control and prevent 
communicable diseases such as HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria in the CLV countries. 
However,  acute  respiratory  infections,  infectious  diarrhea,  typhoid,  cholera,  food-borne 
diseases, dengue, and parasitic diseases are significant causes of morbidity and mortality. 
These  diseases,  increasingly  being  referred  to  as  neglected  endemic  diseases,  are  often 
concentrated in poor and ethnic minorities living in remote rural areas (or urban slums in the 
case of dengue). Thus, neglected diseases primarily affect poor and vulnerable communities, 
and they disproportionately affect women and children. The high morbidity from neglected 
diseases  affects  school  attendance,  cognitive  development,  physical  growth,  and  overall 
productivity. Worm infestations like helminthiasis, filariasis, and schistosomiasis, which receive 
very little donor attention, make up a special group of neglected diseases. Controlling these 
infections would result in major health and education benefits to children. Highly cost-effective 
interventions are available to manage most  common infections, but budget shortages and 
selective donor priorities have hampered provincial and local health offices to tackle these 
common problems. 
 
29.  In  addition  to  the  comparatively  low  funding  for  neglected  endemic  diseases,  the 
prevention and treatment of these diseases is hampered by the absence of an integrated 
approach to dealing with them at the district and community levels. Integrated local planning for 
managing these diseases is insufficient (or absent). Local health planning and services usually 
take a selective approach to prioritized diseases. The CLV countries have implemented the 
IMCI Program, which manages acute childhood illnesses in an integrated manner, but the 
program is not well funded and has limited coverage. Moreover, IMCI is often not implemented 
well, because disparate vertical programs are often not integrated and dominate the local health 
workers’ time and attention as well-funded donors’ programs take precedence. These programs 
should  be  mainstreamed  in  comprehensive  provincial  and  district  health  plans  through  an 
integrated PHC mechanism. The comprehensive, integrated care mechanism should also link 
directly to the surveillance and response system, whereby health workers providing treatment 
for endemic diseases also feed into the reporting system.  
 
2.  Vulnerable Populations 
30.  Mobile Populations. A priority in the GMS has been facilitating connectivity among the 
member countries through the provision of transport infrastructure. Greater connectivity results 
in higher flows of people and goods across borders, bringing both benefits and consequences. 
One of the most problematic consequences is the spread of communicable diseases such as 
sexually transmitted infections and HIV/AIDS as construction workers, traders, transportation 
providers, laborers, and service women move into other areas. Busy border crossing areas tend 
to have among the highest prevalence rates of HIV/AIDS and other communicable diseases. 
 
31.  Remote Populations. Populations residing in remote locations including border areas 
are often very poor and lack physical access to health-care providers. In parts of the Mekong 
Region, people may have to travel more than 25 kilometers on foot to a health post. Both public 
and private sector health-care provision decreases as population density falls, as providers find 
it difficult to work in these places. Outreach teams find it difficult to reach remote villages, 
resulting in lower coverage of immunization and other preventive services in these communities. 
Quarantine stations located at borders can help increase coverage for local populations.

8   
 
32.  Ethnic Minorities. About 60 different ethnic groups live in the GMS. From what is 
known, they share a high communicable disease burden. Remoteness, migration, language and 
social  issues  present  major  obstacles  to  providing  health  care  to  ethnic  minorities.  These 
problems are compounded by the scarcity of health personnel from ethnic minorities. The Lao 
PDR  has  developed  an  innovative  approach  to  grooming  health  staff  from  ethnic  minority 
groups, which appears to be working well.  
 
33.  Poor Women and Children. Gender equity considerations run through all the MDGs, 
including the health-related MDGs. Goal 3, to promote gender equality and empower women, 
has targets and indicators related to gender equality in education and literacy, improvements in 
women’s  income,  poverty  related  to  the  share  of  women’s  wage  employment,  as  well  as 
women’s representation issues, all of which are important to improving women and children’s 
health and the health standards of society overall. Gender considerations are emerging as key 
issues in CDC. It is widely recognized that gender inequality is a principal factor in the HIV/AIDS 
pandemic and sexually transmitted infections. Communicable diseases such as malaria are a 
major contributing factor to maternal mortality. Youth are also increasingly at risk of HIV/AIDS 
another infectious because of social changes and increasing travel in the region. Children are 
more vulnerable to infectious diseases than adults, and to delayed or inappropriate medical 
care. 
 
3.  Challenges in National Health Systems  
34.  The ultimate purpose of health sector development is to develop a health system that is 
appropriate to a country’s needs and resources, including those related to infectious diseases. 
CDC has to be an integral part of the health system, and indeed bring about positive changes in 
the health system as experienced with the HIV/AIDS control program in Cambodia. There are 
many  generic  issues  in  the  health  system  that  affects  CDC,  including  human  resource 
constraints,  the  management  of  health  services,  and  affordability  and  financing  of  health 
services.  CDC  must  also  cope  with  several  specific  challenges  including  (i)  integration  of 
disease control programs in PHC; (ii) staff constraints for preventive care; (iii) standard setting 
and regulation for CDC, in particular for drugs and for private sector regulation; and (iv) regional 
surveillance and response.  
 
35.  The  health systems  in the  three countries  feature  a  dichotomy  between  preventive 
programs, usually managed centrally, and provincial health services focusing on treatment. The 
countries lack a comprehensive approach to health system development; as a result, there are 
coordination  problems  and  inefficiencies  in  the  health  system.  Current  donor  funding 
mechanisms amplify this situation such that periodic ad hoc and unsustainable investments are 
made in particular programs or disease interventions, to the extent that these also undermine 
other services. Of critical importance in the CLV countries is the development of competent 
provincial health planning, budgeting, management, and monitoring capacity, with the provinces 
having  responsibility  and  authority  for  health  sector  performance,  including  preventive 
programs. 
 
36.  In all three countries, there is insufficient training and skills in epidemiology among the 
health  staff  who  are  responsible  for  disease  programs.  Therefore,  the  countries  tend  to 
participate  mainly  in  nationally  organized  activities.  A  challenge  is  to  decentralize  CDC 
management  to  the  provinces,  and  reduce  overlap  in  training,  laboratory  services,  and 
supervision. Such problems have arisen in part because of the lack of comprehensive and 
coordinated planning.

9
 
37.  Although the extensive surveillance network covers all levels down to the commune 
health centers, the coverage and functioning of the surveillance and response systems need 
strengthening. This also applies to diseases that receive substantial attention and support. 
Surveillance  is  further  complicated  by  the  use  of  several  separate  systems  for  prioritized 
diseases that receive financial and technical support from international organizations. As many 
people, especially in remote regions, use private health-care providers, a significant amount of 
information  regarding  communicable  diseases  is  missing  as  it  is  not  part  of  the  current 
surveillance and response system. The village level appears the weakest link because of the 
geographical and social barriers, and perhaps the low priority given to prevention. 
 
4.  Shortage of Regional Public Goods 
38.  RPGs receive less attention than global public goods and national public goods, despite 
the fact that RPGs can help attain global and national public goods. In particular, rates of return 
on regional investments are often higher than individual country investments and reduce high 
costs for smaller economies. This applies equally to RPGs in the health sector. 
 
39.  Clear gaps in RPGs related to health exist within the Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations (ASEAN) and the GMS countries. First, there is no comprehensive regional health 
information system. Several attempts at regional data and information sharing have been made 
(such as ASEAN Disease Surveillance.net, MBDSP, Asian Collaborative Training Network for 
Malaria  Web  site,  ADB,  and  WPRO);  none  of  these  has  so  far  achieved  a  satisfactory 
information  database.  Sharing  of  health  information  will  require  capacity  building  and  also 
confidence building among the governments. Research with a regional perspective is minimal. 
Research related to mobility across borders is particularly important for HIV/AIDS. 
 
40.  Aid agencies often prefer to invest in country-focused programs because of the need to 
establish ownership and the relative ease of arranging lending and grants with a single country. 
Broader-scale health initiatives by the key multilateral institutions tend to be global in scope 
instead of responding to particular regional needs and solutions. These global initiatives prevail 
over regional ones despite the complexities involved in implementing them worldwide, and they 
tend to lose focus on the “weak links” (i.e., countries with limited capacities) that reduce the 
overall effectiveness of global health initiatives. 
 
41.  The current setting appears in need of regional collaboration in CDC. WHO is revising 
the IHR. The forthcoming revisions will provide member countries with a common reference 
point to prevent global health threats and to coordinate international responses to those threats. 
An important element will be regional capacity building. The recent epidemics have created 
more political will to exchange information, harmonize quality standards, and learn key lessons 
from one another. Additionally, a major landmark was achieved in 2003 when the six GMS 
ministers of health signed an agreement to share information as part of the MBDSP financed by 
the Rockefeller Foundation. Progress in ASEAN and GMS has created a strong institutional 
framework for regional collaboration beyond trade and infrastructure issues.  
 
42.  Regional cooperation in the health sector among the GMS countries will require building 
trust and confidence through more frequent and focused dialogue and exchange; developing 
networks across the MOHs, public and private health institutes, and other relevant stakeholders; 
learning  from  one  another’s  experiences;  exchanging  information;  and  embarking  on  joint 
research on critical regional health issues. Once the trust and networks are in place, then the 
GMS countries can move on to more challenging regional cooperation health initiatives such as  
synchronizing disease control strategies, and setting regional standards for goods and services.

D.  External Assistance  
 
43.  The CLV countries receive substantial external assistance to help meet the challenges 
they face in the health and other sectors. However, assistance for regional CDC has been 
limited. ADB has provided modest regional support for HIV/AIDS and malaria control.9 Canada, 
the European Union, WHO and other United Nations agencies also support regional CDC. In 
response to the threat of an AI pandemic, ADB, Australia, Canada, France, the European 
Union, the United States, and the World Bank are planning major support for AI control, some of 
which will be regional.   
 
44.  At country level, total disbursements for Cambodia’s health sector reached $90.3 million

E.  Lessons Learned 
 
47.  Experience with regional projects is limited. As regional projects are more complex than 
national projects, there is a risk of following a vertical approach in planning regional projects that 
undermines national efforts for integration and decentralization, and may not be sustainable. On 
the other hand, regional projects supportive of national programming can work as a catalyst 
through  exchanging  ideas,  challenging  governments  and  creating  a  favorable  climate  for 
change. Strong regional coordination and support as provided in the regional Community Action 
for the Prevention of HIV/AIDS (footnote 9) has shown to be critical in achieving project impact.  
 
48.  The CLV countries are slow to start up new projects. Several projects took more than a 
year to get the implementation arrangements and consulting services in place.16 But after that 
initial delay, the projects usually proceed well. The proposed project will therefore make use of 
existing administrative capacity of ongoing projects (footnotes 12, 13, and 16).  
 
49.  The  public  health  systems  in  CLV  countries  are  facing  serious  staff  and  budget 
constraints, which in turn affect the capacity of Governments to implement and sustain projects. 
Any project activity should be included in the projections for health sector spending in the 
coming years, and projects should undertake substantial capacity building at all levels.   
     
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcomes 
50.  The overall anticipated impact of the GMS Regional CDC Project is to contain the 
spread of epidemic diseases at local level and reduce the burden of common endemic diseases 
in  CLV  countries  by  about  15%  in  the  targeted  provinces,  and  more  for  certain  specific 
infections. This will help these countries progress toward their health-related MDGs for 2015 of 
reducing the child mortality rate and containing the spread of HIV/AIDS and other infections.17 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
51.  The expected project outcomes are (i) timely and adequate control of epidemics that are 
likely to have a major impact on public health and the economy in the region; (ii) improved 
coverage  of  prevention  and  care  of  communicable  diseases  in  vulnerable  populations,  in 
particular poor women and children living in border areas; and (iii) improved know-how, policies, 
standards, and coordination among countries to improve CDC, including for HIV/AIDS, through 
intergovernmental cooperation.  
 
52.  Activities  under  the  Project  are  pro-poor,  focusing  on  PHC  and  community-based 
activities in priority provinces. Women and children will be the major beneficiaries of community 
interventions. Priority will be given to CDC in remote areas including border provinces where 
many ethnic groups and the poorest reside.

B.  Components and Outputs 
53.  The Project has three components: (i) strengthening national surveillance and response 
systems; (ii) improving CDC for vulnerable groups; and (iii) strengthening regional cooperation 
in CDC, linking regional, national and provincial levels. In summary, the component outputs are:   
 
(i)  Comprehensive national surveillance and response systems, including institutional 
structures;  preparedness,  surveillance,  and  response;  laboratory  services;  and 
HRD—in all three countries nationwide. 
 
(ii)  Expanded and integrated CDC for vulnerable groups in 26 provinces (5 in Cambodia, 
6 in Lao PDR, and 15 in Viet Nam). Most of the project provinces have a high 
proportion of vulnerable groups including ethnic minorities and a high burden of 
communicable diseases, and are located along borders or transport corridors.  
 
(iii)  Productive  regional  coordination  for  CDC18  through  capacity  building  of  MOH, 
regional policy dialogue, support for regional institutions in operations research for 
HIV/AIDS  control  and  other  fields  in  support  of  this  dialogue,  and  project 
management.   
 
54.   The Project will be implemented over a period of 4 years and will be adjusted yearly on 
the basis of AOPs to be approved by the national steering committee (SC).   
 
1.  Component 1: Strengthening National Surveillance and Response Systems 
55.  Component 1 is designed to support the development of national surveillance, response, 
and preparedness systems for communicable diseases in the CLV countries, with a particular 
focus on preparedness for emerging infectious diseases (e.g., AI, SARS, and dengue) and 
selected endemic diseases such as cholera and typhoid. The activities will mainly involve 
building capacity so that the countries and the region can meet their obligations related to 
implementing “Early Warning of Outbreaks and Response Systems,” as required in the draft 
revisions of the IHR. The component will help develop and implement plans for detecting and 
responding to emerging infectious diseases, and specifically to the threat of pandemic influenza. 
It will also help strengthen surveillance of priority diseases not covered by national programs. 
The four “building blocks” are (i) institutional structures, partnerships, and policies; (ii) systems 
of  surveillance,  response,  and  preparedness;  (iii)  laboratory  services  and  facilities;  and 
(iv) HRD. 
 
56.  The first subcomponent, strengthening institutional structures, partnerships, and policies, 
will help strengthen communication and collaboration across institutional structures in reviewing 
and revising policies and legislation to facilitate surveillance and response, and in developing 
long-term strategic plans for controlling communicable diseases. Models and mechanisms will 
be developed to strengthen partnerships within the health sector and with other sectors. Current 
legislation and regulations for communicable diseases surveillance and response, including 
those  related  to  border  quarantine,  will  be  reviewed  and  developed  to  support  the 
implementation of the revised IHR (once these are endorsed by the WHO Assembly). 
 
57.  The second subcomponent will help strengthen all elements and linkages in the systems 
of surveillance, response, and preparedness. It will be modeled on the WHO guidelines for

these forums is to coordinate the implementation of project activities under the component, 
discuss  emerging  issues,  and  exchange  experiences  and  knowledge  about  ways  of

58.  The  third  subcomponent,  strengthening  laboratory  facilities  and  services,  will  help 
strengthen  the  capacity  of  reference  and  provincial  laboratories  to  diagnose  priority 
communicable  diseases,  and  enable  the  laboratories  to  participate  effectively  in  outbreak

and testing of specimens, and waste disposal) will be developed and implemented. Mechanisms 
will also be developed to facilitate information sharing between laboratories across the country, 
and  between  laboratories  and  the  preventive  health  centers.  A  national  laboratory-based 
surveillance system for selected pathogens will be developed. The ADB-funded Strengthening 
Preventive  Health  System  Support  Project20  in  Viet  Nam  will  support  the  development  of 
provincial laboratories and, to a lesser extent, the four regional institutions. In collaboration with 
this other project, the Project will identify gaps in services across all levels and support their 
strengthening. 
 
59.  The fourth subcomponent, HRD, will focus on in-service training. The first steps in this 
process will be to document the current and the expected future roles and responsibilities of 
staff at the various levels of the surveillance and response system. The gaps thus identified in 
current  roles  will  form  the  basis  for  customizing  the  training  programs  to  local  needs.  A 
continuing  education  program  (in-service  workshops,  outbreak  simulation  exercises,  and 
regional fellowships) will be developed and implemented for all levels of the health workforce, 
including hospital and laboratory services. Middle and senior managers will attend international 
courses in leadership, information management, and the effective use of national data for 
evidence-based policy development, and in health care financing and resource management. 
Support will be provided to universities and other training institutions for medical professionals in 
developing  and  implementing  undergraduate  curricula  in  surveillance,  response,  and 
preparedness, and in implementing the revised IHR. In Viet Nam, a Field Epidemiology Training 
Program will be developed, and support will be provided for master’s-level training in public 
health and epidemiology in the region and overseas.

the three countries, especially their border provinces with large vulnerable populations. The 
component  will  address  preventable  endemic  communicable  diseases  that  now  receive

62.  For the second subcomponent, several diseases that pose a heavy burden on poor 
communities, many living in border areas, have been identified. While these diseases could be 
eradicated or controlled with new medicines and other measures, funding has been lacking, as 
these are considered minor problems on a national scale. The selection of diseases for the 
component, done in consultation with MOHs, was based on those that are (or could become)

also  be  supported.  Regional  forums  will  provide  opportunities  for  the  CLV  countries  to 
coordinate implementation, discuss emerging issues and progress, and exchange experiences 
and knowledge about controlling these diseases. 
 
63.  For the third subcomponent, continuum of care for HIV/AIDS control will be implemented 
in particular “hot spots” with high-risk populations and along major transport corridors. Selected 
provinces will be the focus areas for HIV/AIDS activities under the Project. Activities will include  
those targeted for laborers and service women at construction sites, peer education programs, 
testing and counseling, and treatment with antiretroviral drugs, similar to those in the successful 
ADB project (footnote 9). Once again, a series of regional technical forums will be held during 
the  Project  to  discuss  progress  and  emerging  issues  in  HIV/AIDS.  Additionally,  the 
subcomponent will link to component 3, operations research for regional HIV/AIDS research and 
related activities.

3.  Component 3: Strengthening Regional Cooperation in CDC  
64.  The common health sector challenges facing the CLV countries present opportunities for 
intensified or new forms of regional cooperation. The cross-border nature of many diseases 
necessitates standard setting and joint action. Regional cooperation provides opportunities for 
learning what works and what does not, provides greater leverage for support, and helps 
optimize the allocation of resources and scale up efforts in key areas that can generate the most 
benefits.  
 
65.  An explicit component for regional cooperation in CDC is deemed necessary to provide 
the leverage and policy focus that specific collaboration on surveillance and disease control may 
lack, and facilitate cross-border dialogue. Hence, the main purposes of this component are to 
enhance  regional  cooperation  in  CDC  among  the  CLV  countries  and  create  sustainable 
foundations for future cooperation. More specifically, the subsidiary objectives are: (i) increase 
capacity for health system development in general and health policy and legal frameworks in 
particular across the region; (ii) promote learning, research, and information exchange across 
the health sectors of the three countries; and (iii) promote coordination in disease prevention 
and control across borders. 
 
66.  Three subcomponents have been designed: (i) regional coordination for dialogue on 
CDC, (ii) regional operations research and institutional linkages, and (iii) project management. 
The formulation of subcomponents and their corresponding activities was based on selected 
criteria, some of which are drawn from the criteria of the GMS Working Group on HRD for 
priority projects. Regional activities should (i) be of national significance to each country and be 
based on identifiable common interests and goals; (ii) create sustainable foundations (i.e., not 
be a “one-off” activity); (iii) provide cross-country learning and sharing; (iv) have an impact on 
inequalities within and between the countries; and (v) provide better economies of scale where 
applicable. Overall, regional cooperation should bring added value to national health systems 
and RPGs for health (see also Appendix 5).  
 
67.  In  response  to  critical  needs  in  the  health  systems  of  the  CLV  countries,  the  first 
subcomponent will promote regional coordination and peer dialogue among the CLV countries 
and other GMS countries. First, one or two regional SC meetings will be held each year during 
the Project to assess project implementation and progress, coordinate activities, and identify 
key issues. The SC will also decide on joint studies. Second, technical forums will be held on 
the following: (i) specific diseases targeted under the Project, (ii) CDC financing and health 
systems development, (iii) the targeting of vulnerable groups for health services, (iv) regulations 
and standards in the health sector, and (v) regional surveillance and response for emerging 
diseases like AI. The main purpose of these forums is to strengthen health systems by (i) 
carrying out dialogue on the issues; (ii) exchanging ideas and experiences in health policies, 
laws, financing options, and interventions; and (iii) exploring opportunities to coordinate and 
harmonize policy and legal standards.  
 
68.  The second subcomponent focuses on regional operations research for HIV/AIDS and 
the development of linkages among institutions in the GMS for other types of joint research and 
demand-based initiatives. The Project will support a series of high-quality research studies on 
particular regional aspects of the HIV/AIDS’s epidemiology in the three countries by building on 
the extensive database (including baseline and final surveys, prevalence surveys, and records 
of input/output data) generated by JFPR 9006 (footnote 9). Key topics for research include: 
(i) emerging patterns of trafficking in women and the impact on HIV/AIDS, (ii) vulnerability and 
risk associated with transport corridors, (iii) road construction and other major infrastructure

16   
development, and (iv) mobility of labor (formal and informal) within and between countries. Also, 
this subcomponent will promote institutional linkages among health and other institutions in the 
three  countries  through  an  innovative  approach  to  joint  research  and  the  development  of 
successful  interventions  that  are  based  on  geography  (as  opposed  to  formal  international 
boundaries)  in  cross-border  settings  or  pertain  to  all  three  countries  at  the  national  level. 
Consortia of institutions (e.g., health institutions, health departments, women’s unions, and 
others) will be invited to develop project proposals and compete for research funds set aside for 
the Project (a summary of the procedure is in Appendix 5). Priority projects for funding include 
financing and health systems development, the targeting of vulnerable groups, cross-border 
health issues, and health regulations and standards (such as those for private sector health 
providers).  
 
69.  The third subcomponent entails overall project management. The regional SC for the 
Project, based on the committee that oversaw the project preparatory TA for this project, will be 
continued. A regional coordination unit (RCU) will be set up in Hanoi. It will function as a 
secretariat of the regional SC to assist the executing agencies in the CLV countries, coordinate 
the TA, and provide administrative backstopping. The regional SC meetings will be organized by 
the agency hosting a particular meeting and the RCU. Additionally, the RCU will be responsible 
for the regional coordination of the TA, including liaison with stakeholders; data and document 
collection; support for international consultants; logistics support; and organization of project 
workshops  involving  all  three  countries.  This  subcomponent  will  also  include  any  required 
project monitoring and reporting responsibilities not assigned to the CLV countries in their 
individual agreements with ADB. 
 
70.  Overall, the regional coordination and dialogue component will have four key outputs, 
namely: (i) greater capacity to strengthen health systems in the region, (ii) greater capacity for 
(and  use  of)  knowledge  sharing  and  institutional  linkages  across  the  CLV  countries, 
(iii) application of “better practices” and successful experiences in policies and interventions, 
and (iv) foundations for sustainable and broader health sector cooperation in the future. 
 
71.  Finally,  for Component  3,  it  is  worth  noting  that  ADB  is  now  preparing  a  strategic 
approach to regional cooperation in response to the rapid changes in the international system 
and throughout Asia-Pacific, to position itself both to support existing regional cooperation 
initiatives and to be prepared to facilitate new forms of regional cooperation that will promote 
regional development. ADB’s Regional and Sustainable Development Department is leading 
this initiative for an ADB-wide strategic approach to regional cooperation. The draft report (as of 
March 2004) of the strategic approach paper advocates focusing on selected priorities and 
RPGs that cut across the Asia-Pacific region, and one suggested priority area is HIV/AIDS. 
Hence, the Project would complement the proposed strategic approach.  
 
C.  Special Features 
72.  Evidently, the first special feature of the Project is the regional approach that it takes to 
CDC  and  health  systems  development.  Typically,  health  systems  improvement  and  CDC 
activities are conducted in national and local settings. The Project involves regional or bilateral 
initiatives among the CLV countries, including joint disease control activities and forums for 
exchanging lessons learned and reviewing needs and progress.  
 
73.  During the GMS HRD working group, all six countries expressed strong support for a 
regional CDC project. However, they decided that the Project would focus on the CLV countries. 
It  is  hoped  that  a  second  phase  will  include  other  GMS  countries  (PRC,  Myanmar,  and

17
Thailand). The Project supports the participation of these countries as observers in the regional 
SCs and as participants in regional technical forums.  
 
74.  Another feature of the Project is its emphasis on using regional cooperation for national 
health systems development. Ultimately, national and local governments are, by and large, 
responsible for ensuring the health of their citizens, and need to develop the system design, 
legislation, and resources to make this happen. While health policy and strategies cut across 
borders, health interventions are largely a national, if not local, responsibility. Hence, regional 
collaboration needs to strengthen national health systems to be relevant, and it is a powerful 
tool for that purpose, through such means as creating a climate of constructive learning and 
competition among the countries. 
 
75.  The Project provides important policy support for national health systems development 
that is in line with the current know-how on improving the effectiveness and efficiency of health 
systems. It focuses on strengthening the provincial health services using sound management 
principles, and on integrating CDC to improve coverage and efficiency.  
 
76.  Rather than creating a new regional institution, the Project aims to strengthen and 
institutionalize regional coordination in MOHs and ensure that it is provided with its own budget, 
staff, responsibilities, and authority. 
 
77.  The Project will strengthen regional initiatives. Some of these entail obligations deriving 
from their membership in global and regional organizations, such as WHO and the ASEAN, 
while others are national initiatives supported by a variety of donors. Specifically, the GMS 
Governments are supporting various initiatives in regional CDC and want to strengthen their 
collaboration.  They  are  working  toward  a  comprehensive,  sustainable  system  for  regional 
collaboration in CDC in the GMS and eventually in ASEAN. Most important in the context of 
control of emerging diseases is that WHO will soon require its members to attain the revised 
IHR. The Project will provide important capacity building for IHR. 
 
78.  The Project also has important externalities beyond the health sector, by generating 
political goodwill and cooperation among sectors. This will further reinforce the GMS spirit of 
peace, prosperity, and poverty reduction.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
104.  Project Benefits and Beneficiaries. The Project will help improve the health of the 
targeted  population  and  thereby  increase  their  productivity,  and  help  progress  toward  the 
health-related  MDGs.  The  Project  will  improve  prevention  and  control  of  communicable 
diseases,  intergovernmental  cooperation  in  containing  and  eliminating  diseases,  and  also 
contribute to strengthening national health systems.  
 
105.  Activities under the Project are targeted toward the poor in general and those living in 
remote locations including border areas, where many ethnic groups and the most poor reside. 
Women and children will be the major beneficiaries of these community-level interventions.   
 
106.  Analysis of Economic and Financial Sustainability. The economic benefits of the 
Project  will  come  from  (i)  helping  prevent  major  epidemics;  (ii) productivity  gains  from  an 
increased lifespan and reduced mortality; (iii) productivity gains from improved achievements in 
education, especially through less absenteeism and reduced dropout rates; and (iv) public and 
private savings in health expenditures, including indirect costs.

25
107.  The Project’s recurrent costs include integrated service delivery staff costs, procurement 
of medical supplies, and ongoing institutional strengthening costs, which together will account 
for about $1.7 million in 2009, the year of projection completion. It is envisaged that recurrent 
costs would be scaled back to about $1.1 million in 2012 as the Project demonstrates the 
benefits of using items like worm tables and larvicides for dengue and households purchase 
such items. The summary economic and financial analysis is in Appendix 13. 
 
108.  Environment. The Project will not have any significant adverse environmental effects. In 
general, it will finance preventive health services, which leave limited by-products, and will help 
safeguard the environment by putting in place an early warning and response system. This will 
help  reduce  the  environmental  costs  of  disease  control,  in  particular  insecticide  spraying. 
Project supervision will closely monitor the issue of medical wastes. 
  
109.  Social Analysis. The targeted provinces have a high proportion of families living below 
or near the poverty line who depend on subsistence farming for their survival, in particular 
among ethnic minorities. They depend heavily on the availability of a healthy labor force in the 
family. Any serious disease or death in the family may throw the family into even deeper 
poverty, malnutrition, and ill health. The summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in 
Appendix 14.  
 
110.  Gender. The Project is focusing on health problems of the poor, in particular women and 
children, and should not have any adverse social impacts for women and children. The Project 
will mainstream women’s (including ethnic women) specific health concerns to ensure that 
health services take into account their cultural and biological differences. The Project also 
includes specific interventions benefiting poor children most, such as deworming of school 
children.  Prevention  of  disease  and  epidemics  will  generally  help  households  improve 
productivity, and thereby reduce food shortages. A gender analysis was undertaken during 
project preparation to ensure that women receive adequate support from the Project (Appendix 
15). Based on this gender analysis, each coordinating IA will prepare country-specific gender 
plans for project implementation. 
 
111.  Ethnic Minorities. Ethnic minorities constitute a major proportion of the population in 
the three countries, and often reside in relatively remote hills and forests where living conditions 
are  difficult.  They  suffer  disproportionately  from  common  communicable  diseases  such  as 
malaria, diarrheal diseases, and worm infections, and also have less access to health care 
because  of  physical,  financial,  language,  and  cultural  barriers.  The  Project  is  specifically 
targeting ethnic groups in the selection of provinces, types of interventions, and planning and 
monitoring arrangements. The ethnic minority development plan is in Appendix 16.   
 
112.  Risks. The Project has some technical risks in the effectiveness of control measures. 
Technical risks will be mitigated by partnering with WHO, hiring national consultants for local 
capacity  building,  and  strengthening  provincial  and  community  involvement.  Institutional 
networking and regional collaboration will also help in strengthening stakeholder involvement.  
 
113.  Previous ADB projects showed project management to be critical to achieving results. 
Each coordinating IA will have a project management unit, which will be supported by existing 
project  administrative  capacity  in  MOH  in  areas  like  planning,  procurement,  financial 
management, monitoring, and reporting.   
 
114.  Regional cooperation requires considerable front-end costs with low immediate returns 
because of an “incubation period.” However, these costs should be offset by substantial benefits

26   
from regional disease control, technology transfer, and strengthened national commitment for 
health sector development, all of which will have long-term value across the region. ADB will 
need to provide substantial support for regional cooperation and ensure that this becomes fully 
institutionalized in terms of budget, staff, responsibility, and authority in the ministries. 
 
115.  The sustainability of new services after project completion is a key risk. In Lao PDR, the 
Project will increase the total public health budget by about 4.5% as public health spending is 
currently very low. The Government of the Lao PDR is planning a substantial increase in public 
health spending over 2006–2010. The fiscal situation is expected to have improved substantially 
by  the  time  of  project  completion.  The  Government  of  Viet  Nam  has  updated  Decrees 
73/1999/ND-CP of 18 August 1999 and 10/2002/ND-CP of 16 January 2002 to ensure the 
implementation  of  Resolution  05/2005/NQ-CP  of  18  April  2005  to  improve  health  sector 
financing.  Each  Government  is  committed  to  sustaining  the  capacity  for  operating  the 
surveillance and response and integrating CDC systems in the targeted provinces. Supplies of 
essential drugs, a direct pro-poor intervention, will be the major items of recurrent costs. The 
Project  will  help  the  Governments  plan  for  these  supplies,  and  will  also  encourage  self-
treatment where applicable and preventive health behavior to contain recurrent costs.

127.  Environment. Each Government, through MOHs, will ensure that the operation of all

128.  Accounting  and  Audit.  Each  Government  will  apply  sound  accounting  standards
